title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement joshua.lambert@lshtm.ac.uk. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to epiparameter
text: outlines propose change epiparameter.

title: Contributing to epiparameter
text: want make change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See bug report template. feature request see feature request.

title: Contributing to epiparameter
text: See pull request template Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("epiverse-trace/epiparameter", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to epiparameter
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to epiparameter
text: Please note epiparameter project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

what: Extract distribution parameters from percentiles or median and range
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: Studies usually report summary statistics distributions fit. mean variance (equivalently standard deviation coefficient variation) provided can easily converted parameters lognormal, gamma weibull distribution. epiparameter provides functions calculate conversion. percentiles, median range provided parameters distribution can estimated. functionality useful new data arises percentiles median range reported. epiparameter provides function allows parameters gamma, lognormal, weibull distributions percentiles median ranges reported literature. example 75th percentiles reported lognormal distribution Nolen et al. (2016) incubation period Monkeypox. instead percentiles, median range provided, done Thornhill et al. (2022) monkeypox, want calculate parameters lognormal distribution, function can applied.
code: # Monkeypox lnorm from 75% percentiles in WHO data extract_param(   type = "percentiles",   values = c(6, 13),   distribution = "lnorm",   percentiles = c(0.125, 0.875) ) #>         a         b  #> 2.1783545 0.3360684 # Monkeypox lnorm from median and range in 2022: extract_param(   type = "range",   values = c(7, 3, 20),   distribution = "lnorm",   samples = 23 ) #>         a         b  #> 1.9460783 0.4934628

what: Conversion of distribution parameters from mean and standard deviation
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: epiparameter provides functions convert parameters distribution mean standard deviation distribution. case mean standard deviation gamma distribution provided, shape scale required gamma_meansd2shapescale() function can used convert two. Donnelly et al. (2003) provides mean variance gamma distribution incubation period SARS. opposite transformation also available gamma_shapescale2meansd(). Converting parameters lognormal distribution mean standard deviation can also accomplished lnorm_musigma2meansd(), reverse transformation uses lnorm_meansd2musigma().
code: # SARS gamma shape/scale from mean and sd gamma_meansd2shapescale(6.37, sqrt(16.7)) #> $shape #> [1] 2.429754 #>  #> $scale #> [1] 2.621664

what: Delay distributions for informing quarantine period
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: epidemics, understanding delay becoming exposed infectious disease onset symptoms (.e. incubation period) informative defining possible quarantine period. Quarantine exposed individuals one widely used nonpharmaceutical intervetions (NPIs) suppress transmission bring basic reproduction number (\(R_0\)) . pointed Nishiura (2009) using right-skewed probability distribution non-zero probability extremely large quarantine periods (e.g. 100 days). epiparameter packages contains range distributions variety infectious diseases can used determine quarantine period. period defined desired proportion people exit quarantine without later going develop symptoms infect others. illustrate example using SARS-CoV pathogen. can check information epiparameter database incubation period SARS-CoV: can see rows 16-17 two studies reporting incubation period SARS-CoV. use Lessler et al. (2009). default specifying SARS_CoV pathogen interest due largest sample size. sure extracting correct study also possible specify study use. Now distribution, case lognormal distribution best-fit parameters incubation period. distributions easily visualised.  order determine duration quarantine period SARS-CoV can calculate percentiles distribution. example, calculate 95th percentile lognormal distribution SARS-CoV example number days within 95% individuals incubation period elapsed. Therefore, eight half days quarantine capture just 90% symptom onset events. increase 95% people require 10.3 days, extreme scenario example 99% people require 15.3 day quarantine period. Given steps outlined database infectious diseases provided epiparameter possible juxtapose incubation periods different pathogens. demonstrate comparison SARS-CoV MERS-CoV. corona viruses (genus Betacoronavirus), zoonotic pathogens produced outbreaks different effects.  95th percentile SARS-CoV incubation period slightly longer 10.3 days compared MERS-CoV 10.0. implication 95% threshold quarantine can slightly shorter MERS.
code: list_distributions(delay_dist = "incubation") #>             pathogen_id        study_id year size distribution #> 1            adenovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   14        lnorm #> 2                 ebola        WHO_team 2014  500        gamma #> 3             human_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009   13        lnorm #> 4  influenza_A_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009  122        lnorm #> 5  influenza_B_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009   76        lnorm #> 6       influenza_H1N1p      Ghani_etal 2009   16        gamma #> 7       influenza_H1N1p      Tuite_etal 2010  316        lnorm #> 8        influenza_H7N9    Cowling_etal 2013   32        gamma #> 9               marburg    Martini_etal 1973    5        gamma #> 10              measles    Lessler_etal 2009   56        lnorm #> 11             MERS_CoV Cauchemez_et_al 2014    7        lnorm #> 12             MERS_CoV     Assiri_etal 2013   23        lnorm #> 13        parainfluenza    Lessler_etal 2009   11        lnorm #> 14           rhinovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   28        lnorm #> 15                  RSV    Lessler_etal 2009   24        lnorm #> 16             SARS_CoV   Donnelly_etal 2003   57        gamma #> 17             SARS_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009  157        lnorm #> 18  SARS_CoV_2_wildtype    McAloon_etal 2020 1269        lnorm #> 19            monkeypox           Nolen 2016   16        lnorm # get epidemiological parameters for incubation period without specifying study sars_cov_incub <- epidist(pathogen = "SARS_CoV", delay_dist = "incubation") # get epidemiological parameters for incubation period specifying study epidist(   pathogen = "SARS_CoV",   delay_dist = "incubation",   study = "Lessler_etal" ) #> Pathogen: SARS_CoV #> Delay Distribution: incubation #> Distribution: lnorm #> Parameters: #>   meanlog: 1.3862935 #>    sdlog: 0.5762278  # specify a different study epidist(   pathogen = "SARS_CoV",   delay_dist = "incubation",   study = "Donnelly_etal" ) #> Pathogen: SARS_CoV #> Delay Distribution: incubation #> Distribution: gamma #> Parameters: #>   shape: 2.43121 #>    scale: 2.62009 plot(sars_cov_incub) # 90th, 95th and 99th percentile percentile qlnorm(   p = c(0.9, 0.95, 0.99),   meanlog = sars_cov_incub$param[["meanlog"]],   sdlog = sars_cov_incub$param[["sdlog"]] ) #> [1]  8.370881 10.320208 15.283897 mers_cov_incub <- epidist(pathogen = "MERS_CoV", delay_dist = "incubation")  plot(mers_cov_incub) # 95th percentile for SARS-CoV-2 qlnorm(   p = 0.95,   meanlog = sars_cov_incub$param[["meanlog"]],   sdlog = sars_cov_incub$param[["sdlog"]] ) #> [1] 10.32021  # 95th percentile for MERS-CoV qlnorm(   p = 0.95,   meanlog = mers_cov_incub$param[["meanlog"]],   sdlog = mers_cov_incub$param[["sdlog"]] ) #> [1] 9.964475

what: Delay distributions for estimating \(R_0\), \(R_t\) and forecasting
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: order calculate rate transmission infectious disease form either basic reproduction number (\(R_0\)) (.e. average number secondary infections primary infection given entirely susceptible population) effective reproduction number (\(R_t\)) (.e. average number secondary infections primary infection point time t given partially susceptible population) requires knowledge certain delay distributions. demonstration use three methods (R packages), EpiEstim, EpiNow2, R0 explore utility delay distributions epiparameter package downstream analysis. information methods used can found respective documentation well Epidemic modelling chapter EpiRHandbook. data used examples come either data stored EpiEstim, EpiNow2, R0 packages loaded outbreaks package.

previous_headings: Delay distributions for estimating \(R_0\), \(R_t\) and forecasting
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: EpiEstim provides toolkit quantify transmissibility infectious disease. main function used example estimate_R(). uses data case incidence serial interval (see Cori et al. (2013) details methods). incidence data used potential SARS-CoV-2 cases NHS outbreaks package (?covid19_england_nhscalls_2020 information). serial interval can specified parametric distribution parameters. mean standard deviation distribution – EpiEstim discrete gamma distribution – arbitrarily chosen. However, epiparameter provides library serial interval parameters can extracted used reproduction number estimation. epidemic curve incidence H1N1 flu cases, estimated \(R_t\) value bottom facet serial interval distribution used calculation \(R_t\). incidence data required calculation \(R_t\) sometimes available raw data form, linelist. linelist incidence data can extracted used reproduction number calculation.
code: # load the data data("covid19_england_nhscalls_2020")  # create incidence data from linelist covid_incidence <- incidence(   x = covid19_england_nhscalls_2020,   date_index = "date" )  # create tibble with correct column names for `EpiEstim` covid_incidence <- tibble(   date = covid_incidence$date_index,   I = covid_incidence$count )  Rt <- estimate_R(   incid = covid_incidence,   method = "parametric_si",   config = make_config(list(     mean_si = 1.8,     std_si = 1.1   )) ) #> Default config will estimate R on weekly sliding windows. #>     To change this change the t_start and t_end arguments. #> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `dates`. list_distributions(delay_dist = "serial_interval") #>            pathogen_id          study_id year size distribution #> 26               ebola WHO_response_team 2014   92        gamma #> 27 SARS_CoV_2_wildtype     Ferretti_etal 2020  191        lnorm #> 28           monkeypox             UKHSA 2022  336        lnorm  covid_si <- epidist(   pathogen = "SARS_CoV_2_wildtype",   delay_dist = "serial_interval" )  Rt <- estimate_R(   incid = covid_incidence,   method = "parametric_si",   config = make_config(list(     mean_si = covid_si$param[["meanlog"]],     std_si = covid_si$param[["sdlog"]]   )) ) #> Default config will estimate R on weekly sliding windows. #>     To change this change the t_start and t_end arguments. #> Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `dates`.  plot(Rt) #> Warning: It is deprecated to specify `guide = FALSE` to remove a guide. Please #> use `guide = "none"` instead.

previous_headings: Delay distributions for estimating \(R_0\), \(R_t\) and forecasting
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: EpiNow2 second R package demonstration data epidemiological parameters (incubation period, serial interval, etc.) can used estimating effective reproduction number (\(R_t\)) used determine transmissibility epidemic real-time growth decline. EpiNow2 differs EpiEstim incorporation delays (e.g. reporting delays) produced less biased estimates Rt.  example generation time incubation period used stored EpiNow2 package. However, data distributions limited comprehensive library distributions provide robust data source make calculations \(R_t\). epiparameter comes . example distributions epiparameter used parameters delay distributions need extracted put list format epinow(). example use 0.1 value standard deviation mean standard deviation distribution parameters information currently available epiparameter.
code: generation_time <- get_generation_time(   disease = "SARS-CoV-2",   source = "ganyani" ) incubation_period <- get_incubation_period(   disease = "SARS-CoV-2",   source = "lauer" ) reporting_delay <- list(   mean = convert_to_logmean(3, 1),   mean_sd = 0.1,   sd = convert_to_logsd(3, 1),   sd_sd = 0.1,   max = 10 )  reported_cases <- example_confirmed[1:40] # estimate Rt by date of infection out <- epinow(   reported_cases = reported_cases,   generation_time = generation_time,   rt = rt_opts(prior = list(mean = 2, sd = 0.1)),   delays = delay_opts(incubation_period, reporting_delay),   stan = stan_opts(samples = 750, chains = 4),   return_output = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE ) plot(out) incubation_period <- epidist(   pathogen = "SARS_CoV_2_wildtype",   delay_dist = "incubation" ) serial_interval <- epidist(   pathogen = "SARS_CoV_2_wildtype",   delay_dist = "serial_interval" )  reporting_delay <- list(   mean = convert_to_logmean(3, 1),   mean_sd = 0.1,   sd = convert_to_logsd(3, 1),   sd_sd = 0.1,   max = 10 )  reported_cases <- example_confirmed[1:40]  # use lnorm_musigma2meansd() to convert the parameters of the lognormal to the # mean (expectation) and standard deviation serial_interval_mean_sd <- lnorm_musigma2meansd(   mu = serial_interval$param[["meanlog"]],   sigma = serial_interval$param[["sdlog"]] )  incubation_period_mean_sd <- lnorm_musigma2meansd(   mu = incubation_period$param[["meanlog"]],   sigma = incubation_period$param[["sdlog"]] )  # for now serial interval is used in place of generation time generation_time_list <- list(   mean = serial_interval_mean_sd$mean,   mean_sd = 0.1,   sd = serial_interval_mean_sd$sd,   sd_sd = 0.1,   max = 20 )  incubation_period_list <- list(   mean = incubation_period_mean_sd$mean,   mean_sd = 0.1,   sd = incubation_period_mean_sd$sd,   sd_sd = 0.1,   max = 20 ) # estimate Rt by date of infection out <- epinow(   reported_cases = reported_cases,   generation_time = generation_time_list,   rt = rt_opts(prior = list(mean = 2, sd = 0.1)),   delays = delay_opts(incubation_period_list, reporting_delay),   stan = stan_opts(samples = 750, chains = 4),   return_output = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )

previous_headings: Delay distributions for estimating \(R_0\), \(R_t\) and forecasting
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: R package R0 contains set functions estimate basic reproduction number (\(R_0\)) effective reproduction number (\(R_t\)). demonstrate calculate time-varying \(R_t\) using method Wallinga Teunis (2004). method uses epidemic curve incidence data course epidemic generation time. calculate \(R_t\) using data outbreak ebola Sierra Leone 2014 outbreaks, using serial interval epiparameter proxy generation time. confidence interval \(R_t\) calculated using simulations number iterations specified argument nsim. run small number simulations purpose demonstration, however, larger number iterations recommended (e.g. 10,000). Estimated value \(R_t\) incidence data ebola Sierra Leone 2014.
code: data("ebola_sierraleone_2014")  ebola_incidence <- incidence(   x = ebola_sierraleone_2014,   date_index = "date_of_onset" )  # format incidence data for `estimate.R()` ebola_incidence_R0 <- ebola_incidence$count names(ebola_incidence_R0) <- ebola_incidence$date_index  ebola_si <- epidist(pathogen = "ebola", delay_dist = "serial_interval")  si_mean_sd <- gamma_shapescale2meansd(   shape = ebola_si$param[["shape"]],   scale = ebola_si$param[["scale"]] )  mGT <- generation.time(type = "gamma", val = c(si_mean_sd$mean, si_mean_sd$sd)) out <- estimate.R(   epid = ebola_incidence_R0,   GT = mGT,   begin = 1,   end = 27,   methods = "TD",   nsim = 100 ) #> Warning in est.R0.TD(epid = c(`2014-05-18` = 1L, `2014-05-20` = 2L, `2014-05-21` #> = 4L, : Accurate confidence interval for R(t) requires a large number of #> simulations. Consider increasing 'nsim' #> Warning in est.R0.TD(epid = c(`2014-05-18` = 1L, `2014-05-20` = 2L, `2014-05-21` #> = 4L, : Using initial incidence as initial number of cases. plot(out$estimates$TD)

title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: epiparameter database stores information several delay distributions. Parameters single delay distribution can extracted using epidist(), comparison data specific pathogen pathogen_summary() can used. incubation period serial interval can compared Monkeypox. Comparison incubation period, serial interval onset hospital admission ebola.
code: epidist(pathogen = "monkeypox", delay_dist = "incubation") #> Pathogen: monkeypox #> Delay Distribution: incubation #> Distribution: lnorm #> Parameters: #>   meanlog: 2.1783545 #>    sdlog: 0.3360684 epidist(pathogen = "monkeypox", delay_dist = "serial_interval") #> Pathogen: monkeypox #> Delay Distribution: serial_interval #> Distribution: lnorm #> Parameters: #>   meanlog: 2.4191716 #>    sdlog: 0.3286863 pathogen_summary(pathogen = "monkeypox") #>    pathogen      delay_dist distribution      mean       sd study #> 1 monkeypox      incubation        lnorm  9.344856 3.231307 Nolen #> 2 monkeypox serial_interval        lnorm 11.860213 4.005986 UKHSA #>                                                                                                                                                       DOI #> 1                                                                                                                                  10.3201/eid2206.150579 #> 2 https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/monkeypox-outbreak-technical-briefings/investigation-into-monkeypox-outbreak-in-england-technical-briefing-1 pathogen_summary(pathogen = "ebola") #>   pathogen         delay_dist distribution mean       sd             study #> 1    ebola         incubation        gamma  5.1 2.167949          WHO_team #> 2    ebola onset_to_admission        gamma  5.1 2.167949          WHO_team #> 3    ebola    serial_interval        gamma 15.3 9.300000 WHO_response_team #>                    DOI #> 1 10.1056/NEJMc1413884 #> 2 10.1056/NEJMc1413884 #> 3 10.1056/NEJMc1413884

title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: default plotting range time since infection zero ten days. can altered specifying day_range argument plotting epidist object.
code: plot(sars_cov_incub, day_range = 1:20)

title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: Currently function epiparameter convert parameters Weibull distribution mean standard deviation. function come future version package. often uncertainty estimates mean, median percentiles parametric distribution, lognormal (e.g. Lessler et al. (2009)). Currently, epiparameter handle uncertainty, future versions incorporate allow uncertainty propagated tools use delay distributions. example, EpiEstim can also estimate reproduction number uncertainty serial interval (see example ), future version epiparameter uncertainty delay distributions, including serial interval, included database available use calculations.
code: data("Flu2009")  Rt <- estimate_R(   incid = Flu2009$incidence,   method = "uncertain_si",   config = make_config(list(     mean_si = 2.6,     std_mean_si = 1,     min_mean_si = 1,     max_mean_si = 4.2,     std_si = 1.5,     std_std_si = 0.5,     min_std_si = 0.5,     max_std_si = 2.5   )) ) #> Default config will estimate R on weekly sliding windows. #>     To change this change the t_start and t_end arguments.

what: Contributing to library of delay distributions
title: Introduction to epiparameter
text: like contribute different delay distributions stored epiparameter package, can access google sheet add data. Notes spreadsheet: interested studies report distribution fitted data. example, mean standard deviation reported unknown distribution, parameters distribution inferred. Shape scale columns parameters gamma distribution, meanlog sdlog columns parameters lognormal distribution. cases values reported study can extracted using epiparameter function extract_param() using either reported percentiles median range (see extraction section) extracted column refers whether distribution parameters explicitly stated paper, case extracted column “”, extracted summary statistics using function package, case extracted column “yes” Discretised indicate whether study fitted discrete distribution Phase_bias means study adjusted either rising falling epidemic, can bias incubation period estimates. studies adjust bias. fields known study, either put “NA” “yet checked”. also happy receive papers report delay distributions can add database .

title: Library of epidemiological parameters
text: R package epidemiological parameter distributions infectious diseases. Eventually include range pathogens natural history processes, well functions extract parameters reported statistics.

title: Library of epidemiological parameters
text: easiest way install development version epiparameter use devtools package:
code: # install.packages("devtools") library(devtools) install_github("epiverse-trace/epiparameter") library(epiparameter)

title: Library of epidemiological parameters
text: view available distributions, define desired function, e.g. extract plot daily probability mass function incubation period influenza H7N9:
code: # View available distributions epiparameter::list_distributions(delay_dist = "incubation") #>             pathogen_id        study_id year size distribution #> 1            adenovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   14        lnorm #> 2                 ebola        WHO_team 2014  500        gamma #> 3             human_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009   13        lnorm #> 4  influenza_A_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009  122        lnorm #> 5  influenza_B_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009   76        lnorm #> 6       influenza_H1N1p      Ghani_etal 2009   16        gamma #> 7       influenza_H1N1p      Tuite_etal 2010  316        lnorm #> 8        influenza_H7N9    Cowling_etal 2013   32        gamma #> 9               marburg    Martini_etal 1973    5        gamma #> 10              measles    Lessler_etal 2009   56        lnorm #> 11             MERS_CoV Cauchemez_et_al 2014    7        lnorm #> 12             MERS_CoV     Assiri_etal 2013   23        lnorm #> 13        parainfluenza    Lessler_etal 2009   11        lnorm #> 14           rhinovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   28        lnorm #> 15                  RSV    Lessler_etal 2009   24        lnorm #> 16             SARS_CoV   Donnelly_etal 2003   57        gamma #> 17             SARS_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009  157        lnorm #> 18  SARS_CoV_2_wildtype    McAloon_etal 2020 1269        lnorm #> 19            monkeypox           Nolen 2016   16        lnorm  # Extract incubation period distribution incubation_H7N9 <- epiparameter::epidist(   pathogen = "influenza_H7N9",    delay_dist = "incubation" )  # Plot probability mass function plot(0:10,incubation_H7N9$pmf(0:10),xlab="time since infection")

what:
Distribution (PDF, CDF, PMF) and its parameters for epidemiological
characteristics of a pathogen — epidist
title:
Distribution (PDF, CDF, PMF) and its parameters for epidemiological
characteristics of a pathogen — epidist
text: Parametric probability distribution (lognormal, gamma, weibull) epidemiological characteristics (incubation period, onset admission, onset death, serial interval) various pathogens. distributions associated best-fit parameters can used inform modelling estimation epidemiological metrics (e.g. reproduction number) public health decisions (e.g. quarantine period).

title:
Distribution (PDF, CDF, PMF) and its parameters for epidemiological
characteristics of a pathogen — epidist
code: epidist(pathogen, delay_dist, study = NULL)

title:
Distribution (PDF, CDF, PMF) and its parameters for epidemiological
characteristics of a pathogen — epidist
text: pathogen character specifying pathogen interest delay_dist character specifying type parameter: "incubation", "onset_to_admission", "onset_to_death" study character specifying dataset use. Defaults study largest sample size.

title:
Distribution (PDF, CDF, PMF) and its parameters for epidemiological
characteristics of a pathogen — epidist
text: Produces object class epidist composed : pathogen: pathogen interest dist: best-fit distribution literature, either study largest sample size (default) specific study (using study argument) delay_dist: metric interest, either "incubation", "onset_to_admission", "onset_to_death" param: parameters distribution pmf, pdf, cdf: distributions: probability mass function (pmf), probability density function (pdf) cumulative distribution function (cdf)

title:
Distribution (PDF, CDF, PMF) and its parameters for epidemiological
characteristics of a pathogen — epidist
text: Adam Kucharski

title:
Distribution (PDF, CDF, PMF) and its parameters for epidemiological
characteristics of a pathogen — epidist
code: # list_distributions() will show which pathogens are available for each # metric here we search for which incubation periods are available list_distributions(delay_dist = "incubation") #>             pathogen_id        study_id year size distribution #> 1            adenovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   14        lnorm #> 2                 ebola        WHO_team 2014  500        gamma #> 3             human_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009   13        lnorm #> 4  influenza_A_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009  122        lnorm #> 5  influenza_B_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009   76        lnorm #> 6       influenza_H1N1p      Ghani_etal 2009   16        gamma #> 7       influenza_H1N1p      Tuite_etal 2010  316        lnorm #> 8        influenza_H7N9    Cowling_etal 2013   32        gamma #> 9               marburg    Martini_etal 1973    5        gamma #> 10              measles    Lessler_etal 2009   56        lnorm #> 11             MERS_CoV Cauchemez_et_al 2014    7        lnorm #> 12             MERS_CoV     Assiri_etal 2013   23        lnorm #> 13        parainfluenza    Lessler_etal 2009   11        lnorm #> 14           rhinovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   28        lnorm #> 15                  RSV    Lessler_etal 2009   24        lnorm #> 16             SARS_CoV   Donnelly_etal 2003   57        gamma #> 17             SARS_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009  157        lnorm #> 18  SARS_CoV_2_wildtype    McAloon_etal 2020 1269        lnorm #> 19            monkeypox           Nolen 2016   16        lnorm  # example of epidist() using incubation period for ebola epidist(pathogen = "ebola", delay_dist = "incubation") #> Pathogen: ebola #> Delay Distribution: incubation #> Distribution: gamma #> Parameters: #>   shape: 5.53404 #>    scale: 0.921569  # when more than one study is available in the database a study can be # specified epidist(   pathogen = "MERS_CoV",   delay_dist = "incubation",   study = "Cauchemez_et_al" ) #> Pathogen: MERS_CoV #> Delay Distribution: incubation #> Distribution: lnorm #> Parameters: #>   meanlog: 1.70475 #>    sdlog: 1.70475  # example using onset to admission as the metric epidist(pathogen = "ebola", delay_dist = "onset_to_admission") #> Pathogen: ebola #> Delay Distribution: onset_to_admission #> Distribution: gamma #> Parameters: #>   shape: 5.53404 #>    scale: 0.921569

what:
Calculate the parameters of a parametric probability distribution from
reported values of percentiles, or median and range — extract_param
title:
Calculate the parameters of a parametric probability distribution from
reported values of percentiles, or median and range — extract_param
text: Summary data distributions, provided reports meta-analyses, can used extract parameters chosen distribution. Currently available distributions : lognormal, gamma weibull.

title:
Calculate the parameters of a parametric probability distribution from
reported values of percentiles, or median and range — extract_param
code: extract_param(   type = c("percentiles", "range"),   values,   distribution = c("lnorm", "gamma", "weibull"),   percentiles,   samples )

title:
Calculate the parameters of a parametric probability distribution from
reported values of percentiles, or median and range — extract_param
text: type character defining whether summary statistics based around percentiles (default) range values vector. type = percentiles: c(percentile_1, percentile_2); type = range: c(median, min, max) distribution character specifying distribution use. Default lnorm; also takes gamma weibull. percentiles vector two elements specifying percentiles defined values using type = "percentiles". samples numeric specifying sample size using type = "range".

title:
Calculate the parameters of a parametric probability distribution from
reported values of percentiles, or median and range — extract_param
text: numeric vector parameter values distribution

title:
Calculate the parameters of a parametric probability distribution from
reported values of percentiles, or median and range — extract_param
text: Adam Kucharski

title:
Calculate the parameters of a parametric probability distribution from
reported values of percentiles, or median and range — extract_param
code: # extract parameters of a lognormal distribution from the 75 percentiles extract_param(   type = "percentiles",   values = c(6, 13),   distribution = "lnorm",   percentiles = c(0.125, 0.875) ) #>         a         b  #> 2.1783545 0.3360684   # extract parameters of a gamma distribution from median and range extract_param(   type = "range",   values = c(8, 6, 13),   distribution = "gamma",   samples = 20 ) #>        a        b  #> 2.285959 4.076114

text: Adam Kucharski

title: List distributions — list_distributions
code: # the default for list_distributions() without any arguments is to return the # incubation period list_distributions() #>             pathogen_id        study_id year size distribution #> 1            adenovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   14        lnorm #> 2                 ebola        WHO_team 2014  500        gamma #> 3             human_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009   13        lnorm #> 4  influenza_A_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009  122        lnorm #> 5  influenza_B_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009   76        lnorm #> 6       influenza_H1N1p      Ghani_etal 2009   16        gamma #> 7       influenza_H1N1p      Tuite_etal 2010  316        lnorm #> 8        influenza_H7N9    Cowling_etal 2013   32        gamma #> 9               marburg    Martini_etal 1973    5        gamma #> 10              measles    Lessler_etal 2009   56        lnorm #> 11             MERS_CoV Cauchemez_et_al 2014    7        lnorm #> 12             MERS_CoV     Assiri_etal 2013   23        lnorm #> 13        parainfluenza    Lessler_etal 2009   11        lnorm #> 14           rhinovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   28        lnorm #> 15                  RSV    Lessler_etal 2009   24        lnorm #> 16             SARS_CoV   Donnelly_etal 2003   57        gamma #> 17             SARS_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009  157        lnorm #> 18  SARS_CoV_2_wildtype    McAloon_etal 2020 1269        lnorm #> 19            monkeypox           Nolen 2016   16        lnorm  # metrics can be chosen using the `delay_dist` argument, for example # incubation period or onset to death list_distributions(delay_dist = "incubation") #>             pathogen_id        study_id year size distribution #> 1            adenovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   14        lnorm #> 2                 ebola        WHO_team 2014  500        gamma #> 3             human_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009   13        lnorm #> 4  influenza_A_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009  122        lnorm #> 5  influenza_B_seasonal    Lessler_etal 2009   76        lnorm #> 6       influenza_H1N1p      Ghani_etal 2009   16        gamma #> 7       influenza_H1N1p      Tuite_etal 2010  316        lnorm #> 8        influenza_H7N9    Cowling_etal 2013   32        gamma #> 9               marburg    Martini_etal 1973    5        gamma #> 10              measles    Lessler_etal 2009   56        lnorm #> 11             MERS_CoV Cauchemez_et_al 2014    7        lnorm #> 12             MERS_CoV     Assiri_etal 2013   23        lnorm #> 13        parainfluenza    Lessler_etal 2009   11        lnorm #> 14           rhinovirus    Lessler_etal 2009   28        lnorm #> 15                  RSV    Lessler_etal 2009   24        lnorm #> 16             SARS_CoV   Donnelly_etal 2003   57        gamma #> 17             SARS_CoV    Lessler_etal 2009  157        lnorm #> 18  SARS_CoV_2_wildtype    McAloon_etal 2020 1269        lnorm #> 19            monkeypox           Nolen 2016   16        lnorm list_distributions(delay_dist = "onset_to_death") #>            pathogen_id    study_id year size distribution #> 25 SARS_CoV_2_wildtype Linton_etal 2020   23        lnorm  # by default list_distributions() will return a filtered table, but if the # full table including extra information (e.g. parameters of the # distribution) the `parameters` argument can be set to `TRUE` list_distributions(delay_dist = "onset_to_admission", parameters = TRUE) #>        pathogen_id            type_id      study_id year size distribution mean #> 20           ebola onset_to_admission      WHO_team 2014  500        gamma   NA #> 21 influenza_H1N1p onset_to_admission    Tuite_etal 2010  316        lnorm   NA #> 22  influenza_H7N9 onset_to_admission  Cowling_etal 2013   32        gamma   NA #> 23        MERS_CoV onset_to_admission   Assiri_etal 2013   23        lnorm   NA #> 24        SARS_CoV onset_to_admission Donnelly_etal 2003   57        gamma   NA #>    sd median quantile_75 quantile_95    shape    scale meanlog    sdlog #> 20 NA     NA          NA          NA 5.534040 0.921569      NA       NA #> 21 NA     NA          NA          NA       NA       NA 2.17531 0.330773 #> 22 NA     NA          NA          NA 9.650000 0.450000      NA       NA #> 23 NA     NA          NA          NA       NA       NA 7.00000 0.750000 #> 24 NA     NA          NA          NA 1.929655 2.513402      NA       NA #>    extracted discretised phase_bias_adjusted            notes     PMID #> 20       yes        <NA>                <NA>             <NA> 25564903 #> 21      <NA>        <NA>                <NA>             <NA> 19959592 #> 22      <NA>        <NA>                <NA>             <NA> 23803488 #> 23      <NA>        <NA>                <NA>             <NA> 23782161 #> 24      <NA>        <NA>                <NA> Feb-26 to Mar-25 12781533 #>                              DOI       added_by #> 20          10.1056/NEJMc1413884 Adam Kucharski #> 21           10.1503/cmaj.091807 Adam Kucharski #> 22 10.1016/S0140-6736(13)61171-X Adam Kucharski #> 23         10.1056/NEJMoa1306742 Adam Kucharski #> 24 10.1016/S0140-6736(03)13410-1 Adam Kucharski
